question.title: Java: how to resolve generic type of lambda parameter?

node.contents: Not sure I understand; in your example you can do without `Integer`, the compiler does type inference here.

astNode.text: Not sure I understand; in your example you can do without `Integer`, the compiler does type inference here.

node.contents: No. I really need to know that type: we have some `converter` subsystem which can convert `"2"` to `int` (the simplest sample), if it can determine the type of parameter. Otherwise we end up with `java.lang.String cannot be cast to java.lang.Integer`. Having that Java somehow understands the actual type. But how can I do that from code?

astNode.text: No. I really need to know that type: we have some `converter` subsystem which can convert `"2"` to `int` (the simplest sample), if it can determine the type of parameter. Otherwise we end up with `java.lang.String cannot be cast to java.lang.Integer`. Having that Java somehow understands the actual type. But how can I do that from code?

</t>

node.contents: We wrap that inline class (or lambda) to some `MethodInvoker` with `converter` ability and call the method using reflection. That's why I need to know actual types to do conversion for provided object before method call

astNode.text: We wrap that inline class (or lambda) to some `MethodInvoker` with `converter` ability and call the method using reflection. That's why I need to know actual types to do conversion for provided object before method call

node.contents: One more time: I want to know **actual generic type of method argument**. I can do that for classes, but can't for lambdas. That's all. Don't try to understand the logic of my application - it is Spring and it has powerfull `Converter` sub-system. E.g. I can write and register some `UserToPersonConverter` and just send the `User` to my consumer and it will be converted to the `Person` method parameter. It works with inline classes, but doesn't with lambdas

astNode.text: One more time: I want to know **actual generic type of method argument**. I can do that for classes, but can't for lambdas. That's all. I can write and register some `UserToPersonConverter` and just send the `User` to my consumer and it will be converted to the `Person` method parameter. It works with inline classes, but doesn't with lambdas

node.contents: When we use it as an inline implementation it isn't so difficult to extract the Integer from the method of that class.

node.contents: Do I miss anything? Or just java doesn't support it for lambda classes ?

node.contents: To be more cleaner:

astNode.text: To be more cleaner:

node.contents: That lambda is wrapped with MethodInvoker (in the mentioned handle), which in its execute(Message<?> message) extracts actual parameters for further reflection method invocation. Before that it converts provided arguments to target params using Spring's ConversionService.

astNode.text: That lambda is wrapped with MethodInvoker (in the mentioned handle), which in its execute(Message<?> message) extracts actual parameters for further reflection method invocation. Before that it converts provided arguments to target params using Spring's ConversionService.

node.contents: The method handle in this case is some configurer before the real application work.

astNode.text: The method handle in this case is some configurer before the real application work.

node.contents: This is good answer too, but there is some performance impact, when the functional interface is `Serializable`. See my linked question with the solution. BTW the same solution is applied for the WebSocket's `session.addMessageHandler`: https://java.net/jira/browse/WEBSOCKET_SPEC-226

astNode.text: This is good answer too, but there is some performance impact, when the functional interface is `Serializable`. See my linked question with the solution. BTW the same solution is applied for the WebSocket's `session.addMessageHandler`: https://java.net/jira/browse/WEBSOCKET_SPEC-226

node.contents: If you created the SAM interfaces yourself, it may be worth adding java.io.Serializable as a superinterface to make this method work.

node.contents: This example will work for `java.util.function.Function` but not for some other functional interfaces since the member ref is located at different indexes. For Oracle JDK and Open JDK the member ref can be reliably obtained via `constantPool.getMemberRefInfoAt(constantPool.size() - 2)`

astNode.text: This example will work for `java.util.function.Function` but not for some other functional interfaces since the member ref is located at different indexes. For Oracle JDK and Open JDK the member ref can be reliably obtained via `constantPool.getMemberRefInfoAt(constantPool.size() - 2)`

node.contents: Thanks Jonathan, I've updated the post

astNode.text: Thanks Jonathan, I've updated the post

node.contents: This is currently possible to solve but only in a pretty hackie way, but let me first explain a few things:

astNode.text: This is currently possible to solve but only in a pretty hackie way, but let me first explain a few things:

node.contents: When you write a lambda, the compiler inserts a dynamic invoke instruction pointing to the LambdaMetafactory and a private static synthetic method with the body of the lambda. The synthetic method and the method handle in the constant pool both contain the generic type (if the lambda uses the type or is explicit as in your examples).

astNode.text: When you write a lambda, the compiler inserts a dynamic invoke instruction pointing to the LambdaMetafactory and a private static synthetic method with the body of the lambda. The synthetic method and the method handle in the constant pool both contain the generic type (if the lambda uses the type or is explicit as in your examples).

node.contents: Now at runtime the LambdaMetaFactory is called and a class is generated using ASM that implements the functional interface and the body of the method then calls the private static method with any arguments passed. It is then injected into the original class using Unsafe.defineAnonymousClass (see John Rose post) so it can access the private members etc.

astNode.text: Now at runtime the LambdaMetaFactory is called and a class is generated using ASM that implements the functional interface and the body of the method then calls the private static method with any arguments passed. It is then injected into the original class using Unsafe.defineAnonymousClass (see John Rose post) so it can access the private members etc.

node.contents: Unfortunately the generated Class does not store the generic signatures (it could) so you can't use the usual reflection methods that allow you to get around erasure

astNode.text: Unfortunately the generated Class does not store the generic signatures (it could) so you can't use the usual reflection methods that allow you to get around erasure

node.contents: For a normal Class you could inspect the bytecode using Class.getResource(ClassName + ".class") but for anonymous classes defined using Unsafe you are out of luck. However you can make the LambdaMetaFactory dump them out with the JVM argument:

astNode.text: For a normal Class you could inspect the bytecode using Class.getResource(ClassName + ".class") but for anonymous classes defined using Unsafe you are out of luck. However you can make the LambdaMetaFactory dump them out with the JVM argument:

node.contents: By looking at the dumped class file (using javap -p -s -v), one can see that it does indeed call the static method. But the problem remains how to get the bytecode from within Java itself.

astNode.text: By looking at the dumped class file (using javap -p -s -v), one can see that it does indeed call the static method. But the problem remains how to get the bytecode from within Java itself.

node.contents: This unfortunately is where it gets hackie:

astNode.text: This unfortunately is where it gets hackie:

node.contents: Using reflection we can call Class.getConstantPool and then access the MethodRefInfo to get the type descriptors. We can then use ASM to parse this and return the argument types. Putting it all together:

astNode.text: Using reflection we can call Class.getConstantPool and then access the MethodRefInfo to get the type descriptors. We can then use ASM to parse this and return the argument types. Putting it all together:

elements.contents: Method getConstantPool = Class.class.getDeclaredMethod("getConstantPool"); getConstantPool.setAccessible(true); ConstantPool constantPool = (ConstantPool) getConstantPool.invoke(lambda.getClass()); String[] methodRefInfo = constantPool.getMemberRefInfoAt(constantPool.size() - 2); int argumentIndex = 0; String argumentType = jdk.internal.org.objectweb.asm.Type.getArgumentTypes(methodRef[2])[argumentIndex].getClassName(); Class<?> type = (Class<?>) Class.forName(argumentType);

units.rawText: Method getConstantPool = Class.class.getDeclaredMethod("getConstantPool"); getConstantPoolsetAccessible(true); ConstantPool constantPool = (ConstantPool) getConstantPool.invoke(lambda.getClass()); String[] methodRefInfo = constantPool.getMemberRefInfoAt(constantPool.size() - 2); int argumentIndex = 0; String argumentType = jdkinternalorgobjectwebasmTypegetArgumentTypes(methodRef[2])[argumentIndex].getClassName(); Class<?> type = (Class<?>) Class.forName(argumentType);

node.contents: UPDATED with Jonathan's suggestion

astNode.text: UPDATED with Jonathan's suggestion

node.contents: Now ideally the classes generated by LambdaMetaFactory should store the generic type signatures (I might see if I can submit a patch to the OpenJDK) but currently this is the best we can do. The code above has the following problems:

astNode.text: Now ideally the classes generated by LambdaMetaFactory should store the generic type signatures (I might see if I can submit a patch to the OpenJDK) but currently this is the best we can do. The code above has the following problems:

node.contents:
• It uses undocumented methods and classes
  • It is extremely vulnerable to code changes in the JDK
  • It doesn't preserve the generic types, so if you pass List<String> into a lambda it will come out as List

astNode.text:
• It uses undocumented methods and classes
  • It is extremely vulnerable to code changes in the JDK
  • It doesn't preserve the generic types, so if you pass List<String> into a lambda it will come out as List

node.contents:
Works as expected. Thank you very much. now I can do just this: `.
<integer>
 handle((p, h) -> p * 2)` and can convert incoming Object to the expected `Integer` using the same our `conversion` system.
</integer>

 handle((p, h) -> p * 2)` and can convert incoming Object to the expected `Integer` using the same our `conversion` system.
</integer>

node.contents: I recently added support for resolving lambda type arguments to TypeTools. Ex:

astNode.text: I recently added support for resolving lambda type arguments to TypeTools. Ex:

elements.contents: MapFunction<String, Integer> fn = str -> Integer.valueOf(str); Class<?>[] typeArgs = TypeResolver.resolveRawArguments(MapFunction.class, fn.getClass());

units.rawText: MapFunction<String, Integer> fn = str -> IntegervalueOf(str); Class<?>[] typeArgs = TypeResolver.resolveRawArguments(MapFunction.class, fn.getClass());

node.contents: The resolved type args are as expected:

astNode.text: The resolved type args are as expected:

elements.contents: assert typeArgs[0] == String.class; assert typeArgs[1] == Integer.class;

units.rawText: assert typeArgs[0] == String.class; assert typeArgs[1] == Integer.class;

node.contents: Note: The underlying implementation uses the ConstantPool approach outlined by @danielbodart which is known to work on Oracle JDK and OpenJDK (and possibly others).

astNode.text: Note: The underlying implementation uses the ConstantPool approach outlined by @danielbodart which is known to work on Oracle JDK and OpenJDK (and possibly others).
